description:
Producer price indices for agricultural products

Explanatory notes for the following statistics:
61211 Index of producer prices of agricultural products

Definition:
The index of producer prices of agricultural products
measures the movement of selling prices in agriculture
(domestic sales). The reference variable of the overall
index is the value of all sales proceeds realised in
agriculture in the base year. As complete monitoring of the
market must cover all sales, the turnover realised between
agricultural enterprises is also included in price
statistics (average farm concept).

As regards the major steps of calculation, the indices can
be referred to as the weighted mean of the price relatives
(average relatives), which are determined for a
representative selection of products (price
representatives). The individual relatives are obtained from
individual price series (of individual reporting units) on
the basis of the (monthly, weighted) prices in the base year
(= 100). Then, for every good, the individual relatives
available for it are taken to form an average relative as a
simple arithmetic mean. The average relatives are weighted
according to the individual price representatives'
importance in terms of turnover or expenditure in the base
year and are aggregated to form the indices for classes,
subgroups, groups and other meaningful groupings, and the
overall index.

The individual price series are based on the results of the
(mainly) monthly collection of prices performed with a
representative sample of reporting units (especially
agricultural cooperatives, rural traders, marketing boards).
The values of an individual price series should reflect only
pure price changes. To achieve this, all factors relevant
for the price level - the price-determining variables - have
to be kept constant for as long as possible. This applies
not only to the quantity unit of the price representatives
monitored and their overall quality, but also to the various
terms of trade, delivery and payment. If one of these
variables changes, the difference between the new price and
the one last reported may contain a non-genuine price
change, which has to be eliminated.

The index is calculated through the Laspeyres formula. This
means that the weights from the current base year will
remain unchanged until the index is put on a new base year.
